For some reason my replies are not coming through. The translation of Milt's
text is Kasuga-no or Kasuga-ya, which means the plains around Kasuga Shrine
in Nara. There is no spring going on here at all. Just autumn, deer and
maples around Kasuga Shrine.

 

Gordon

 

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of David Zincavage
Sent: Wednesday, April 27, 2005 2:34 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba

 

Milt, you did not explain where this text comes from.
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: bungotakadasword 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, April 26, 2005 7:41 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba



  --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@s...> 
  wrote:
  > Hi all,
  > 
  >  
  > 
  > I have tried to find this term, but to no avail. I would like to 
  add,
  > however, that the maple and deer motif is autumnal and not spring. 
  It is
  > also evocative of Nara. I know of no connection with any particular
  > association with a Sengoku period warlord. 
  > 
  >  
  > 
  > Gordon
  > 
  >  
  > 
  Hi Gordon,
  yes we know maples are usually associated with Autumn......however,
  please klick..........
  http://tinyurl.com/cxu33

  Unless I am suffering from some sort of syndrome associated with 
  advancing age, it does read..........
  Spring day in the wild ( Red leaves, deer )picture tsuba, mumei, ko-
  kinko.
  then yada yada yada ( the dimension etc ), 17th cent.


  milt
